Award.AwardTitle: NSF/FDA Scholar In Residence: Vessel Rupture Thresholds for Microbubble-Assisted High-Intensity Therapeutic Ultrasound

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT
PI: Khismatullin, Damir
Proposal Number: 1641221

High-intensity focused ultrasound has recently gained recognition as a noninvasive ionizing radiation-free therapeutic method. It is being explored for treatment of cancer, neurological diseases, and circulatory system-related cardiovascular diseases. To avoid permanent damage and to identify vessel rupture thresholds for HITU devices experiments and modeling of bubble dynamics in blood vessels will be performed. This project will lead to a computational tool and a new formula for HITU safety threshold assessment that will give patients in the U.S. faster access to safe devices for treating severely debilitating diseases. It will directly support the research work of a minority graduate student, who is an active member of the Society for Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SAGNAS). The student will receive training in computational fluid dynamics and experimental techniques for stimulation of ex vivo tissues by focused ultrasound.


The outcomes of high-intensity therapeutic focused ultrasound (HITU) significantly depend on the presence of micrometer-size bubbles that can be formed in tissues as a result of acoustic cavitation. The oscillation of microbubbles in an ultrasound field generates mechanical stresses on nearby cells and tissues, leading, for example, to thrombolysis or transient opening of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) for drug delivery to brain tissue. The PI will develop a state-of-the-art computational model the collective dynamics of cavitation of lipid-coated microbubbles in blood vessels and tissues exposed to focused ultrasound. The model will account for tissue viscoelasticity and inhomogeneity and be validated against HITU experiments on rupture of explanted vessels, to determine the critical pressure and stresses on the vessel wall above which the vessel ruptures.

Institution.Name: Tulane University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: ADMINISTRATORS OF THE TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND, THE

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to integrate state-of-the-art computational modeling of bubble-vessel wall interaction with experimental analysis of blood vessel rupture by ultrasound-induced bubble oscillations. This integrated approach is necessary to identify vessel rupture thresholds for therapeutic ultrasound devices employing microbubbles and thus to develop safety criteria for the use of ultrasound devices in the treatment of neurological disorders, cardiovascular diseases, and cancer. We have developed the experimental system and protocol for bubble injection and vessel rupture in tissue-mimicking phantom and in vivo (earthworm) models. We have also developed the computational model for single bubble oscillation in a space confined by deformable, viscoelastic walls and then adapted this model to the geometry and flow conditions mimicking earthworm vasculature. This model is a significant improvement over approximate theories of single bubble nucleation and oscillation, which have a number of assumptions that are not valid for biological tissues. In addition to improved assessment of safety thresholds of therapeutic ultrasound, our integrated experimental-computational approach is a powerful tool to study acoustic cavitation in biological tissues and bubble dynamics in a confined space. This project has supported research training of a minority graduate student at FDA, particularly, in experimental techniques such as diagnostic and therapeutic ultrasound, systems for injection and filtration of microbubbles, tissue-mimicking phantom preparation, and in vivo analysis. 


Last Modified: 10/26/2018
Modified by: Damir B Khismatullin
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this project was to integrate state-of-the-art computational modeling of bubble-vessel wall interaction with experimental analysis of blood vessel rupture by ultrasound-induced bubble oscillations. This integrated approach is necessary to identify vessel rupture thresholds for therapeutic ultrasound devices employing microbubbles and thus to develop safety criteria for the use of ultrasound devices in the treatment of neurological disorders, cardiovascular diseases, and cancer. We have developed the experimental system and protocol for bubble injection and vessel rupture in tissue-mimicking phantom and in vivo (earthworm) models. We have also developed the computational model for single bubble oscillation in a space confined by deformable, viscoelastic walls and then adapted this model to the geometry and flow conditions mimicking earthworm vasculature. This model is a significant improvement over approximate theories of single bubble nucleation and oscillation, which have a number of assumptions that are not valid for biological tissues. In addition to improved assessment of safety thresholds of therapeutic ultrasound, our integrated experimental-computational approach is a powerful tool to study acoustic cavitation in biological tissues and bubble dynamics in a confined space. This project has supported research training of a minority graduate student at FDA, particularly, in experimental techniques such as diagnostic and therapeutic ultrasound, systems for injection and filtration of microbubbles, tissue-mimicking phantom preparation, and in vivo analysis.
